datasets.name: Land cover trends (2001-2021)
datasets.citation: Yang, L., et al. (2018). A new generation of the United States National Land Cover Database: Requirements, research priorities, design, and implementation strategies. ISPRS Journal of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing 146: 108-123.
datasets.description: This dataset shows the amount of area in each major land cover class for 2001, 2004, 2006, 2008, 2011, 2013, 2016, 2019, 2021.  Land cover classes include open water, perennial ice/snow, developed (multiple intensities), barren land, deciduous forest, evergreen forest, mixed forest, shrub/scrub, grassland/herbaceous, pasture/hay, cultivated crops, woody wetlands, and emergent herbaceous wetlands.  Data are only available for Southeastern states within the contiguous U.S.
datasets.valueDescription: Values show the amount of each land cover class that is present within each analysis area for each year data are available from NLCD.  Only those land cover classes that are present within a given analysis area are shown.
datasets.methods: Land cover data for each year were reprojected to match the standard grid used in this tool and clipped to Southeastern states.

datasets.name: Impervious surface trends (2001-2021)
datasets.citation: Yang, L., et al. (2018). A new generation of the United States National Land Cover Database: Requirements, research priorities, design, and implementation strategies. ISPRS Journal of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing 146: 108-123.
datasets.description: This dataset shows percent impervious surface for 2001, 2004, 2006, 2008, 2011, 2013, 2016, 2019, 2021.
datasets.valueDescription: Values show the total amount of impervious surface each analysis area for each year data are available from NLCD.  These are calculated as the total amount of area in each percent level of impervious surface times the percent.
datasets.methods: Impervious surface data were reprojected to match the standard grid used in this tool and clipped to Southeastern states.

datasets.name: Current and projected urbanization
datasets.citation: Center for Geospatial Analytics, NC State University (June 2023)
datasets.description: The FUTURES urban growth model predicts the likelihood that an area will urbanize at every decade from 2030 to 2100. Developed areas from the 2021 National Landcover Database serve as the baseline for current urban areas. The model simulates landscape change based on trends in population growth, local development suitability factors, and an urban patch-growing algorithm. It considers environmental drivers like distance to floodplain, slope, and available infrastructure, and even socio-economic status. The probability of urbanization for each area reflects how many times it urbanized out of 50 model runs.  Limited to the inland continental Southeast.
datasets.valueDescription: Current urbanization is derived from NLCD 2021.  Projected urbanization for 2030 through 2100 is based on the proportion of stochastic simulations out of 50 that predicted a given pixel will convert to urban.  The Low level of urbanization includes areas where at least 50% of the runs predicted that a pixel will convert to urban, and the High level of urbanization corresponds to areas where any of the runs predicted that a pixel will urbanize.  To calculate the total amount of urbanization within each analysis area, the proportion of stochastic urbanization simulations that predict urbanization for a given pixel is multiplied by the area associated with each proportion.
datasets.methods: Urbanization data were converted from floating point probabilities provided by the Center for Geospatial Analytics to the count of stochastic simulations out of 50, and reprojected to match the standard grid used in this tool and clipped to Southeastern states.

datasets.name: Sea-level rise inundation area
datasets.citation: NOAA Office for Coastal Management Sea Level Rise Data: 1-10 ft Sea Level Rise Inundation Extent (2017)
datasets.description: Sea-level rise inundation area data are provided by NOAA in 1 foot increments, based on available digital elevation model data.  These data are used to show the amount of each analysis unit that would be covered by that level of sea-level rise.
datasets.valueDescription: Sea-level rise inundation area data are provided by NOAA in 1 foot increments, based on available digital elevation model data.  Values show the amount of area that would be inundated by that amount of sea-level rise depth based on the number of 30-meter pixels rasterized from NOAA inundation depth polygons that overlap with each analysis unit.
datasets.methods: Sea-level rise polygons were downloaded from NOAA and rasterized to 30m resolution and aligned to match the standard grid used in this tool and clipped to Southeastern states; polygons and holes within polygons smaller than 1/2 pixel were dropped.  Additional areas characterizing the sea-level rise modeling extent were obtained separately from NOAA and used to define areas where data are unavailable, areas where sea-level rise is unlikely to be a threat (inland counties), and areas not projected to be inundated by up to 10ft sea-level rise.

datasets.name: Projected sea-level rise
datasets.citation: Sweet, W.V., B.D. Hamlington, R.E. Kopp, C.P. Weaver, P.L.Barnard, D. Bekaert, W. Brooks, M. Craghan, G. Dusek, T. Frederikse, G.Garner, A.S. Genz, J.P. Krasting, E. Larour, D. Marcy,J.J. Marra, J.Obeysekera, M. Osler, M. Pendleton, D. Roman, L. Schmied, W. Veatch, K.D.White, and C. Zuzak, 2022: Global and Regional Sea Level Rise Scenarios for the United States: Updated Mean Projections and Extreme Water Level Probabilities Along U.S. Coastlines. NOAA Technical Report NOS 01. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, National Ocean Service, Silver Spring, MD
datasets.description: Sea-level rise projections are derived from 1-degree grid cells that accompany the 2022 Sea Level Rise Technical Report by NOAA.  Values show the area-weighted mean of 1-degree grid cells that overlap each analysis unit based on a baseline of 2000.  Sea-level rise scenarios correspond to a global sea level rise of between 1, 1.64, 3.2, 4.9, and 6.56 feet.
datasets.valueDescription: Sea-level rise projections are derived from 1-degree grid cells that accompany the 2022 Sea Level Rise Technical Report by NOAA.  Values show the area-weighted mean of 1-degree grid cells that overlap each analysis unit based on a baseline of 2000.  Sea-level rise scenarios correspond to a global sea level rise of between 1, 1.64, 3.2, 4.9, and 6.56 feet.
datasets.methods: 1-degree grid cell sea-level rise projection data were downloaded from NOAA and limited to those that overlap with areas where sea-level rise inundation depth were modeled by NOAA.

datasets.name: Coastal shoreline condition
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint

values.label: Partially armored and harder to develop

datasets.description: This indicator assesses shoreline condition based on the presence of hardened structures like jetties, groins, and riprap, as well as other human development. By restricting the natural movement of sediment, shoreline armoring increases erosion, prevents the inland migration of coastal ecosystems in response to sea-level rise, and degrades habitat for birds, sea turtles, fish, plants, and other species both on and offshore. Natural shorelines in harder-to-develop coastal areas receive the highest shoreline condition scores, while hardened shorelines receive the lowest scores. This indicator originates from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Environmental Sensitivity Index dataset.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Caribbean Coastal shoreline condition
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.description: This indicator assesses shoreline alteration based on the presence of hardened structures like seawalls, groins, and riprap at the dynamic interface between land and water along the U.S. Caribbean coast. By restricting the natural movement of sediment, shoreline armoring increases erosion, prevents the inland migration of coastal ecosystems in response to sea-level rise, and degrades habitat for birds, sea turtles, fish, plants, and other species both on and offshore. This indicator originates from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Continuously Updated Shoreline Product.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Resilient coastal sites
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.description: This indicator depicts the capacity of coastal habitats to migrate to adjacent lowlands in order to sustain biodiversity and natural services under increasing inundation from sea-level rise. It is based on the physical and condition characteristics of current tidal complexes, their predicted migration space, and surrounding buffer areas. These characteristics include marsh complex size, shared edge with migration space, sediment balance, water quality, natural landcover, landform diversity, and more. This indicator originates from The Nature Conservancy's Resilient Coastal Sites project.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Stable coastal wetlands
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.nodata_label: Not within a stable coastal wetland
datasets.description: This indicator uses remote sensing to calculate the unvegetated-vegetated ratio of tidal wetlands, which compares how much of a wetland is not covered by plants (e.g., sediment, rocks, open water) to how much is covered by plants. Marshes that maintain a higher proportion of vegetation tend to be more stable and resilient to threats like sea-level rise, erosion, and coastal development. This ratio, and how it changes over time, is a good surrogate for salt marsh degradation processes like sediment loss and conversion to open water. This indicator originates from a U.S. Geological Survey project on an unvegetated to vegetated ratio for coastal wetlands.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Natural landcover in floodplains
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.nodata_label: Not within an estimated floodplain or outside floodplain natural landcover data extent
datasets.description: This indicator measures the amount of natural landcover in the estimated floodplain of rivers and streams within each catchment. It assesses the stream channel and its surrounding riparian buffer, measuring the percent of unaltered habitat like forests, wetlands, or open water (rather than agriculture or development). Intact vegetated buffers within the floodplain of rivers and streams provide aquatic habitat, improve water quality, reduce erosion and flooding, recharge groundwater, and more. This indicator originates from the National Land Cover Database and applies to the Environmental Protection Agency's estimated floodplain, which spatially defines areas estimated to be inundated by a 100-year flood (also known as the 1% annual chance flood).
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Caribbean natural landcover in floodplains
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.nodata_label: Not within an estimated floodplain or outside floodplain natural landcover data extent
datasets.description: This indicator measures the amount of natural landcover in the estimated floodplain of rivers and streams within each catchment in the U.S. Caribbean. It assesses the stream channel and its surrounding riparian buffer, measuring the percent of unaltered habitat like forests, wetlands, or open water (rather than agriculture or development) in the floodplain. Intact vegetated buffers within the floodplain of rivers and streams provide aquatic habitat, improve water quality, reduce erosion and flooding, recharge groundwater, and more. This indicator originates from LANDFIRE land cover. It applies to the floodplain predicted to be inundated by a 100-year flood (also known as the 1% annual chance flood), derived from the Federal Emergency Management Agency's National Flood Hazard Layer, and buffered flowlines representing other streams.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Aquatic network complexity
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.nodata_label: Not within an estimated floodplain or outside aquatic network complexity data extent
datasets.description: This indicator depicts the number of connected stream size classes in a river network between dams or waterfalls. River networks with a variety of connected stream classes help retain aquatic biodiversity in a changing climate by allowing species to access climate refugia and move between habitats. This indicator originates from the Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership and applies to the Environmental Protection Agency's estimated floodplain, which spatially defines areas estimated to be inundated by a 100-year flood (also known as the 1% annual chance flood).
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Caribbean aquatic network complexity
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.nodata_label: Not within an estimated floodplain or outside aquatic network complexity data extent
datasets.description: This indicator depicts the number of connected stream size classes in a river network between dams or waterfalls in the U.S. Caribbean. River networks with a variety of connected stream classes help retain aquatic biodiversity in a changing climate by allowing species to access climate refugia and move between habitats. This indicator originates from the Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership. It applies to the estimated floodplain, which spatially defines areas predicted to be inundated by a 100-year flood (also known as the 1% annual chance flood), based on the Federal Emergency Management Agency's National Flood Hazard Layer, and buffered flowlines representing other streams.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Fire frequency
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint

values.label: Not burned from 2013-2021 or row crop

datasets.description: This indicator uses remote sensing to estimate the number of times an area has been burned from 2013 to 2021. Many Southeastern ecosystems rely on regular, low-intensity fires to maintain habitat, encourage native plant growth, and reduce wildfire risk. This indicator combines burned area layers from U.S. Geological Survey Landsat data and the inter-agency Monitoring Trends in Burn Severity program. Landsat-based fire predictions within the range of longleaf pine are also available through Southeast FireMap.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Intact habitat cores
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.description: This indicator represents the size of large, unfragmented patches of natural habitat. It identifies minimally disturbed natural areas at least 100 acres in size and greater than 200 meters wide. Large areas of intact natural habitat are important for many wildlife species, including reptiles and amphibians, birds, and large mammals. This indicator originates from Esri's green infrastructure data.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Resilient terrestrial sites
datasets.citation: Southeast Conservation Adaptation Strategy (SECAS). 2025. Southeast Conservation Blueprint 2025. http://secassoutheast.org/blueprint
datasets.description: This indicator depicts an area's capacity to maintain species diversity and ecosystem function in the face of climate change. It measures two factors that influence resilience. The first, landscape diversity, reflects the number of microhabitats and climatic gradients created by topography, elevation, and hydrology. The second, local connectedness, reflects the degree of habitat fragmentation and strength of barriers to species movement. Highly resilient sites contain many different habitat niches that support biodiversity, and allow species to move freely through the landscape to find suitable microclimates as the climate changes. This indicator originates from The Nature Conservancy's Resilient Land data.
datasets.methods: Data were used without additional modification.

datasets.name: Aquatic barriers
datasets.citation: Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership. 2025.  National Aquatic Barrier Prioritization Tool (version 3.19.0; 7/30/2025).
datasets.description: This dataset includes the count of dams and potential road-related barriers within the HUC12 subwatersheds that overlap the analysis units.  Dams are derived from the Southeast Aquatic Resource Partnership's barrier inventory, which is compiled from multiple sources.  Potential road-related barriers are derived from the USGS Database of Stream Crossings in the U.S.  NOTE: potential road-related barriers include features such as bridges, which may not be barriers to aquatic organism dispersal, as well as culverts with high outlet drops, which are complete barriers to the passage of aquatic organisms.  The degree of impact of these barriers to aquatic organisms has only been surveyed for a very small number of these potential road-related barriers; please see the National Aquatic Barrier Prioritization Tool for more details.
datasets.valueDescription: Values show the total number of dams and potential road-related barriers across all HUC12 subwatersheds that overlap each analysis unit.
datasets.methods: Dams are snapped to the aquatic network and duplicate records resulting from merging multiple source databases are removed where possible.  Duplicate dam records and erroneous data (where known) are omitted here.  Duplicate potential road-related barriers are removed if they co-occur within a 10 meter distance of anotehr road-related barrier.  The total number of dams and potential road-related barriers are calculated for each HUC12 subwatershed.

datasets.name: Aquatic network alteration
datasets.citation: Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership. 2025.  National Aquatic Barrier Prioritization Tool (version 3.19.0; 7/30/2025).
datasets.description: This dataset shows the length of the aquatic network (rivers / streams) that is considered anthropogenically altered by one or more data sources.  The aquatic network is derived from the USGS National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) High Resolution dataset for use in the National Aquatic Barrier Prioritization Tool (https://aquaticbarriers.org/) created by the Southeast Aquatic Resources Partnership.  Flowlines are considered altered if they are coded by NHD as canal / ditch or pipeline type, overlap with altered riverine areas in the National Wetlands inventory, or fall within a reservoir identified by NHD or state water body datasets.  Not all areas of aboveground flow are represented within this dataset, so it should be taken as an approximate measure of aquatic network alteration.  It is not intended to represent all anthropogenic alterations to aquatic ecosystems.
datasets.valueDescription: Values show the percent of the total length of the aquatic network that is considered altered.  Network lengths are combined across all HUC12 subwatersheds that overlap each analysis unit.
datasets.methods: The aquatic network is derived from the USGS National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) High Resolution flowlines dataset, excluding flowlines (rivers / streams) that represent coastlines, underground connections, long pipelines, or lack catchment drainage information.  Flowlines are considered altered if they are coded by NHD as canal / ditch or pipeline type, overlap with altered riverine areas in the National Wetlands inventory, or fall within a reservoir identified by NHD or state water body datasets.

datasets.name: Inundation frequency by land cover class
datasets.citation: Allen, Y. 2016. Landscape Scale Assessment of Floodplain Inundation Frequency Using Landsat Imagery. River Research and Applications 32:1609-1620.
datasets.description: This dataset characterizes the landscape-scale relative inundation frequency. These data can provide information about ecological processes as well as hydrologic alteration in the floodplain. Landsat imagery acquired from 1984-2002 were used to generate multiple observations of inundation extent under varying hydrologic conditions. These data were composited into a landscape mosaic to depict relative inundation frequency over the entire Southeast US. Relative inundation frequency was combined with NLCD 2021 to depict inundation frequency by land cover type.
datasets.valueDescription: Values show the amount of each land cover class that is in each inundation frequency class within each analysis area.  Only those land cover classes that are present within a given analysis area are shown.
datasets.methods: Relative inundation frequency was binned into 5 classes and combined with NLCD 2021 land cover classes in order to describe inundation frequency by land cover class.  Data were reprojected from WGS 1984 to match the standard grid used in this tool and clipped to Southeastern states.
